stem: The nurse reviews the clinical data from 0800 to 1100. Which finding most clearly indicates a therapeutic response to the interventions?

options.text: Decreased respiratory rate from 28 to 24 breaths per minute.
Increased crackles auscultated in all lung fields.
Decreased urine output from 30 mL/hr to 20 mL/hr.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 0800: Pt. exhibiting dyspnea, coarse crackles bilaterally. IV Lasix 40mg administered. O2 via nasal cannula @ 2LPM. 0930: Pt. reports slight improvement in breathing. Crackles still present, but diminished. 1100: Pt. breathing more comfortably. Crackles significantly reduced. Continues on O2 @ 2LPM.

tabs.title: Lab Results
tabs.content: 0730: BNP: 800 pg/mL, Serum Sodium: 138 mEq/L, Serum Potassium: 4.2 mEq/L

tabs.title: Orders
tabs.content: 1. Furosemide 40mg IV STAT, then q12h. 2. Oxygen via Nasal Cannula @ 2LPM. 3. Monitor Vital Signs q1h. 4. Strict I&O. 5. Daily Weights. 6. Low Sodium Diet.

rationale.correctRationale: Increased oxygen saturation from 88% to 94% indicates improved gas exchange in the lungs, signifying a positive response to the diuretic and oxygen therapy. The Lasix is helping to remove excess fluid in the lungs, which improves oxygenation.

incorrectRationales.option_2: While a decreased respiratory rate is a positive sign, it's less direct an indicator of improved gas exchange than the SpO2.
incorrectRationales.option_3: Increased crackles indicate a worsening of pulmonary edema, which would suggest the interventions are not effective.
incorrectRationales.option_4: Decreased urine output suggests the diuretic is not working effectively to remove excess fluid, indicating a lack of therapeutic response.

rationale.clinicalPearls: Monitoring oxygen saturation is critical in patients with pulmonary edema. A rising SpO2 level indicates improved gas exchange and a positive response to treatment. Remember the ABCs: Airway, Breathing, Circulation.
rationale.questionTrap: Many students will focus on respiratory rate, but the SpO2 provides a more direct and objective measure of improved oxygenation in response to treatment.
rationale.mnemonic: Use 'ABCD' - Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Diuresis - to remember the priorities in managing pulmonary edema. Improvement in 'Breathing' (oxygenation) is the key to assessing therapeutic response.
